DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: Package was placed up right and bottle was placed upright as well and the package was placed in a Hazmat container.

  • City: STERLING

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On April 26, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon container of organic peroxide was damaged during transit and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted surface. FCE personnel utilized absorbents, soda ash, and hand tools to collect and containerize the damaged 5-gallon pail and all impacted debris into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • City: FREDERICKSBURG
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was refused by recipient upon discovering that items inside had loose lids. No spill occurred outside of the fiberboard box container. DescribePack: Items inside container were not tightly placed which caused lids to shake come loose off of top of glass containers. 2 500Ml glass bottles were inside container. The bottle containing isopropanol had a loose lid and leaked during transit. DurationRel: 14 and MitigateEffect: Upon discovery, package was contained in a damaged hazmat bin. No vapors were releasing outside of items or container.

item.title: Report X-2023050152
item.description:
Report X-2023050152

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-13T00:37:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-26
  • City: ASHLAND
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: While an outbound package handler was unloading a truck, he noticed a wet area near the hazmat package and alerted QA. The unloading of WA313 truck was halted while QA secured the hazmat package and removed the non-hazmat packages that were affected. QA cleaned up the spill with nonhazardous liquid absorbent in and around the truck and brought the hazmat damage and Non hazmat damages to the QA processing area. DescribePack: Upon inspection of the package and the area the package was leaking, it was found that the Jerrican container had been punctured by a sharp metal piece in the truck. The puncture is located on the corner bottom of the container about the size that a large flathead screwdriver would make. DurationRel: 130 and MitigateEffect: Container was placed in a damaged hazmat container with the punctured area facing up to stop spillage and brought to the QA hazmat area.

item.description:
Report E-2023050024

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-13T00:37:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-18
  • City: RICHMOND
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Veolia employees were unloading a straight truck at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility containing waste from a household hazardous waste event when he noticed that a fiberboard container had leaked onto the containers below it on the pallet. Further investigation revealed a bottle of Windex was improperly placed into the container, but outside of the liner. The Windex bottle had a broken lid which resulted in liquid being spilled inside the box between the outside of the liner and the inside of the box. None of the material reached the floor of the trailer or the loading dock. Both containers affected were properly repacked without injury or further incident.

item.title: Report X-2023040996
item.description:
Report X-2023040996

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-13T00:37:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-17
  • City: WINCHESTER
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was discovered on the vanline conveyor belt to have been leaking from one corner. An employee authorized to handle hazardous materials isolated the package until inspection. DescribePack: Plastic/foil seals underneath screw caps came completely off of the jerricans. Contents of both jerricans leaked through outer packaging, creating fist-sized hole at the top corner of the package and seeping onto that entire side of outer packaging. At time of discovery, the package was already dried up, but much of the damaged side's writing has corroded away. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was isolated by an authorized employee.

item.title: Report E-2023040224
item.description:
Report E-2023040224

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-12T21:09:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-03-13
  • City: ROCKY MOUNT
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ENVIRONMENTAL OPTIONS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: One of the containers (a 275-gallon tote) failed in the warehouse and released its entire contents inside the warehouse. The release was discovered on Monday, March 13, 2023. Notifications were made to WL Black, Broker of Record for the generator, the waste generator and to SE/EO management. SE/EO responded immediately to the release that was contained within the building, deployed spill sorbents and dispatched a cleanup crew and safety representatives. A team of 1 response supervisor, 3 environmental response technicians, 2 site staff and a safety officer and HSE manager responded to the event. The broker/generator provided copies of profile for Nickle plating waste and SDSs for components believed added to one or more containers that had been shipped. Samples of the small amount of waste remaining in the failed tote were collected. These samples were noted to exhibit off-gassing and buildup of pressure within the closed sample container. The other containers appeared to be stable on inspection. Once spread of the release had been secured and contained, SE/EO collected as much of the spilled material as practicable using an empty vacuum truck and cleaned up the waste using granular sorbents, pads and booms. The work team utilized air monitoring equipment and work teams donned USEPA Level C Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) to ensure the safety the work team members during cleanup. The waste, cleanup material and PPE were containerized by placing the waste in one (1) tote (original waste liquid/washwater/surfactant), five (5) drums (granular sorbents, rags and pads) and four (4) drums (sorbent booms and PPE). A mild surfactant (Simple Green) was applied to the affected warehouse floor areas and the affected areas power washed with clean water. All cleaner/washwater was collected and placed into the liquid containing tote noted above.

  • Description: 1. X-2023010812 SequenceEvent: Package was found on the trailer by qa and was taken to the cage. Upon inspection it was found that 3 of the 4 bottles of liquid had their caps come off while in transit leading to the spillage. Because of this fact the qa team placed the shipment into a salvage drum for storage. DescribePack: The package was covered in the liquid that was leaking out of the bottles causing the box to get wet. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The qa team placed the shipment into a salvage drum. 2. X-2023010814 SequenceEvent: Package was found on the trailer by qa and was taken to the cage. Upon inspection it was found that 3 of the 4 bottles of liquid had their caps come off wile in transit leading to the spillage. Because of this fact the qa team placed the shipment into a salvage drum for storage. DescribePack: The package was covered in the liquid that was leaking out of the bottles causing the box to get wet. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The qa team placed the shipment into a salvage drum for storage. 3. X-2023020580 SequenceEvent: Package was found on the van by qa and was taken to the qa cage for inspection. Upon inspection it was found that all 4 of the bottles of UN3149 had their caps loosened while in transit leading to major leakage. Because of this the team placed the shipment into a salvage bin and sealed it. DescribePack: The package failed by being soaked by the liquid hazmat, DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The team placed the shipment into a salvage bin and sealed it.

UPON INSPECTION OF INNER CONTENTS FOUND ONE HOVER-1 BLAST ELECTRIC SCOOTER WITH AN INSTALLED 2 AH/10 CELL LITHIUM-ION BATTERY CLASSIFIED AS UN3171 BATTERY POWERED VEHICLE. PACKAGE ALSO CONTAINS ONE MACBOOK PRO AND TWO APPLE WATCHES CLASSIFIED AS UN3481 LITHIUM-ION BATTERIES CONTAINED IN EQUIPMENT. TWO APPLE EARBUDS WITH CHARGING CASES CLASSIFIED AS UN3481 LITHUIM ION BATTERIES PACKED WITH EQUIPMENT. THE ITEMS WERE SHIPPED IN A LARGE BROWN HOME DEPOT BOX. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX. THIS PACKAGE HAS NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM VIRGINA USING UPS ACCOUNT 8F7F66, N/A, 605 N 21ST STREET, FORT PIERCE FL, 34950.

  • Incident Date: 2022-12-16
  • City: ROANOKE

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: NORFOLK SOUTHERN
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Car was reported leaking by conductor during inspection. Steady drips coming out from around the bottom outlet cap and falling on the ties. We checked the valve and verified it was closed and tried to tighten the cap. We were unalbe to stop the leak. The cap was removed and we found the valve was not holding and a steady stream of product was coming out. We replaced the gasket in the cap and tightened the cap with a 36" wrench. Leak was stopped. We verified leak free for 30 minutes and then released car to be delivered. Shipper was contacted to request OTMA and consignee was contacted to not release car once it was made empty. without an OTMA.

item.title: Report I-2022100001
item.description:
Report I-2022100001

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-12T21:09:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-02
  • City: RURAL RETREAT
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ENVIRONMENTAL OPTIONS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Environmental Options, Inc (EOI) truck was en route to Environmental Enterprises Inc (EEI) in Marion VA with a load of hazardous waste. The tractor became disabled on the shoulder of I-81 at MM 59.5 EOI first contacted EEI who dispatched a tractor to the site to pull the trailer to EEI located in Marion VA. When EEI arrived they discovered something was leaking out of the nose of the trailer and thought a chlorine vapor was observed when checking the load. EEI contacted Leann Herman with Environmental Options of the situation. Ms. Herman then contacted the State Police , First Call Environmental to respond to a hazmat incident. The response time was going to be at least 3 hours. Ms.Herman then reached out to Elizabeth Lohman with the Office of Pollution Response & Emergency Preparedness (Department of Environmental Quality VA). Due to other hazmat on board and the wait time for First Call to be on scene, Scott Sproles the Regional HazMat officer with VDEM was dispatched to the scene of the incident and called in Wythe County Emergency Services to help. During this time the NRC, VEOC were also notified. DEQ contacted Virginia Department of Transportation (VDOT) to dispatch the Safety Patrol Operator to evaluate need for traffic control and a lane closure was put into place. The initial incident report to the NRC indicated it could be chlorine tabs gasing off (Incident Report# 1346219). Once the hazmat crew was on scene and load was transferred to another trailer. A leaking drum of nitric acid was discovered. Ms Herman updated her NRC incident report under (Incident Report # 1346275) to show 10 gallons of nitric acid/nickel solution was released. The leaking poly drum was placed into an overpack and the spilled material was neutralized and collected for proper disposal. A follow up call the NRC was made on 09/03 to update the clean up procedure (Incident report # 1346306).

item.description:
Report E-2022100030

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-12T21:09:05+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-08
  • City: RICHMOND
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 8, 2022, at approximately 1231 hours personnel in the CSXT ACCA yard at Richmond, Virginia, reported an odor in the area of SRIX 17012, a residue tank car last containing Chlorine. The car was isolated and the shipper, Brenntag Mid-South, was notified via CHEMTREC Report #2022-0908-00237. HEPACO, a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to investigate and found a vapor release from the tank cars left side vapor line valve. Contractor personnel found product leaking through the valve while in the closed positon and the secondary closure plug not containing the release. Contractor personnel tightened the secondary closure plug to stop the release. A certified mobile repair unit (MRU) subsequently responded, removed and replaced the faulty valve, and performed a bubble leak test on the repair prior to the car being released for transportation.

  • Description: Kemira's Independent Carrier (TDK Fuller Trucking) was traveling south bound on I95 when the right lane that he was in turned into Exit ramp 53. The driver thought that he was in the lane that continued straight, not the lane that turned into an exit ramp. The driver could not slow down fast enough to make the turn. He locked up the brakes and the truck and trailer rolled on its side. About 4-5 gallons of product leaked from the dome lid as the trailer was on its side. About 2 more gallons leaked while emergency responders were in the process of getting the product pumped out of the trailer and into another trailer. Emergency responders drilled holes in the side of the trailer to pump out the product into a backup trailer. Product was contained to about a 5 ft by 5 ft area that was remediated. Excavators were on site to clean up any contaminated soil.

  • Description: On July 13, 2022, Landstar notified ERTS regarding an unknown hazardous release from cargo on trailer #692943. requesting to dispatch a remediation contractor. Hepaco arrived onsite and a cargo assessment was done and it was concluded that approximately 50 gallons of product leaked from a pinhole size puncture at the bottom of the involved drum. Of the 50-gallons spilled, approximately 30-gallons released outside the trailer to a 1' by 40' area of the asphalt parking lot. The media affected, trailer components and underlying asphalt, were subsequently addressed and waste generated was containerized and is currently pending disposal.
